jumpingoffcliffs.author_byline: Executive Director, Strategy and Technology at CASH Music
jumpingoffcliffs.title: Jumping Off Cliffs
jumpingoffcliffs.description: Art directly creates our culture, driving ideas and enabling communication that goes far beyond language alone.

marksurman.title: Mark Surman, executive director, Mozilla Foundation
marksurman.description: Music is a guiding force, able to steer people toward communities and causes they're passionate about. ...I've been drawn to social causes and organizations that embody that punk passion and sincerity. In a way, music made me.
marksurman.summary: Music is one of the most accessible forms of expression - everyone can listen, and anyone brave enough to hoist a ukulele or beat a drum can participate. It's visceral. Music is also one of the most collaborative forms of expression - the more people, the better it sounds. (At least to the people making it.)

bethditto.title: CASH Music: Beth Ditto
bethditto.description: Tell people how rad they are. I think if you want to keep artists’ voices being heard then tell people that what they do is important.

laurasnapes.author_byline: a contributing editor at Pitchfork who also writes at The Guardian, The Observer, The Financial Times, Uncut and more
laurasnapes.title: Laura Snapes
laurasnapes.description: I think it's the greatest source of joy and comfort of all art forms. And done right, it can foster understanding of and openness to other ways of being like nothing else can.

kimboekbinder.author_byline: a contributing editor at Pitchfork who also writes at The Guardian, The Observer, The Financial Times, Uncut and more
kimboekbinder.title: Kim Boekbinder
kimboekbinder.description: I think it's the greatest source of joy and comfort of all art forms. And done right, it can foster understanding of and openness to other ways of being like nothing else can.

jedwardkeyes.author_byline: writer, editor, beer drinker, film watcher, showgoer, record collector. Editorial Director for Bandcamp.
jedwardkeyes.title: J. Edward Keyes
jedwardkeyes.description: That's always been the music that's excited me the most, when artists question the accepted - in culture, in song structure, in production methods - and tear everything down so they can build it back up again in their own way.

henryrollins.author_byline: a contributing editor at Pitchfork who also writes at The Guardian, The Observer, The Financial Times, Uncut and more
henryrollins.title: Henry Rollins on the impact of music in our world
henryrollins.description: The way millions listen to music has changed radically in the last few decades and that, I think, speaks to the question.

horacepanter.author_byline: Horace Panter, aka Sir Horace Gentleman, bassist of The Specials and professional artist
horacepanter.title: Horace Panter
horacepanter.description: Time stood still. It was transcendental. I knew then that playing music was the greatest thing in the world.

nathanlarson.author_byline: NYC dwelling film composing male, author, diviner, label owner
nathanlarson.title: Nathan Larson
nathanlarson.description: But like all new tech the potential for discovery and access is mind-blowing, and beyond good and evil. The fact is the sample group of kids I have access to are as likely to know as much about obscure '60s garage punk stuff, or classic hip hop, or 'classic' punk rock, and that's extremely fucking cool.

jubileesugar.title: CASH Music Interview Series: EP.2 (Teaser) - Jubilee & Hot Sugar w/ Ashok 'Dap' Kondabolu
jubileesugar.description: [Music]’s everywhere all the time and I don't think people realize what kind of an impact it really has.
